DataElement.preferredName: Other Invasive Breast Carcinoma Histologic Type Specify
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A free text field to describe a response of Other, specify to a question about the invasive breast cancer histologic type.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Other Invasive Breast Carcinoma Histologic Type
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue._A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.:Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.:A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Property.preferredDefinition: Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

Concepts.definition: Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.
